title: 113_hr1076
content: The Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act is amended to include a new section on savings from state authorized public entity health benefits pools. The Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act is amended to include a new section allowing State authorized public entity health benefits pools to apply for funding for health care benefits starting in 2014. The Secretary will approve applications if the coverage is comprehensive and affordable. The Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act is amended to allow State authorized public entity health benefits pools to apply for funding for comprehensive and affordable health care benefits. The approval of applications will result in cost savings to the Federal Government compared to providing benefits through an Exchange. The Secretary will promulgate regulations for pass-through of funding under this section within 90 days of enactment. Applications must be accepted within 180 days. Approved applications will treat individuals as covered under minimum essential coverage for tax purposes. The Secretary will provide an alternative means for individuals and small employers in the pool to receive payments for premium tax credits, cost-sharing reductions, and small business credits under the Internal Revenue Code if they do not qualify for these benefits through an Exchange. The payment amount will be determined based on the sum of these credits that would have been provided. Regulations for pass-through of funding will be promulgated within 90 days of enactment, and approved applications will treat individuals as covered under minimum essential coverage for tax purposes. The Secretary will determine the application of a pool within 180 days of receipt, considering the experience of individuals and small employers in Exchanges. Definitions include 'public entity' as a county. The term 'public entity' refers to various political subdivisions defined under State law. A 'State authorized public entity health benefits pool' is a risk pool regulated by a State agency, providing health care benefits primarily for public entity officials, employees, retirees, and their dependents. The term 'affiliated service contractor' refers to an organization eligible for health care benefits through a state authorized public entity health benefits pool for its officials, employees, retirees, and their dependents.
